content: Investments Asked by AnonymousAsked on 10 Jul 2018Is now a good time to invest in Capitaland Mall Trust?Thinking of putting some money in Capitaland Mall and Frasers Centrepoint Trust. I'm currently invested in STI ETF via RSP ($300/month) with around $30k in cash4 answersAnswerBump2
Answers (4)Sort By Most UpvoteMost UpvoteMost Recent

Marcus GohLevel 3. WonderkidAnswered on 10 Jul 2018I believe you are looking at Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) which is more of a dividend investing. You should know the fundamentals and the things to look out for in REITs to maximum your returns like the Gearing Ratio and Distribution Per Unit (DPU) and ultimately do your due digilence. ​Fifthperson has compiled SG REITs data with Live Daily Updates (According to their website) and you could look more about it and make your choices according after doing your homework.https://sreit.fifthperson.com/0 comments1

Dwivid SharmaLevel 3. WonderkidAnswered on 17 Aug 2018I must say to invest carefully in any stocks, it all your earning and should be invested in safe hands. Moreover, if we talk about  Capitaland Mall and Frasers Centrepoint Trust both are the undervalued stocks, but both has good returns in long term investment. you can check their return stays here https://www.mmfsolutions.sg/blog/best-undervalued-stocks-singapore/0 comments0

Lee JiahuiLevel 5. GeniusAnswered on 17 Jul 2018i wrote a short review on retail reits a few months back. if you are just buying 1 lot (1000 units) of CMT, i think it's still ok, but just be prepared for fluctuations. if you are buying even lesser, just check the transaction fees cos usually brokerage charge about $29 per transaction as minimum. 52 Wk Range: 1.95 - 2.17​http://littletoybrush.blogspot.com/2018/03/stock-review-if-i-were-to-pick-retail.html0 comments0

Randall TanLevel 4. ProdigyAnswered on 10 Jul 2018It is always a good time if you know what you are doing. Always remember, Time in the market and not timing the marketPast performance is not an indicator of future outcomesDo your own due diligence0 comments0
